review_title: An incredible mission/history and no respect for it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Almost across the board, everyone at The New School is genuinely great, creative and interesting. Unless you're super high up, you're probably working there because you're getting a tuition break (HUGE benefit—if you're looking to get a Masters, you can do so essentially for free while working) or you're an artist/academic/musician trying to make a decent living in New York without putting in 14-hour workdays. This makes for incredible connections—most of my closest friends in the world I met through this place. There's always (pre-COVID) free talks, film screenings, and art shows. While working there, I saw Cornel West, bell hooks, Noam Chomsky, Jane Goodall, and so many more key figures of our time. Depending on your job/department/boss, you can be sure to have a normal, dependable schedule. Summer Fridays (7 of them) were a godsend for staff.
cons: I worked for The New School in two departments for about 7 total years. I'm an alum, too, so I came in with an experience of the institution as a person having literally grown from it (this is the case with many employees—former students taking a dependable gig, believing they're giving back). Across the board, The New School is insanely top heavy: people in ridiculously high paying roles (who have been there 7+ years, sometimes longer) doing nothing but making decks and babysitting leadership. If you're under 35, good luck getting anyone to take you seriously—for a project, raise, or a higher position—particularly if you're challenging folks to actually live by the progressive ideals of the institution. I wasn't the only young, energetic person who experienced a kind of slow, sad suffocation—constantly asked to do more and more of the wrong kind of work and discouraged from taking on the real issues (faculty dissatisfaction; overly paid higher ups while worker bee staff members beg for $60K a year; reliance on adjuncts so they don't have to pay for health insurance; overworked/underpaid grad students; students angry because they can barely afford to eat with the high tuition and even higher turnover rate of advisors because advisors, being underpaid and overworked, frequently quit before students can even get to know them, let alone ask for their advice). If you're looking for something with all the pros I mentioned and you don't have too many growth aspirations or mind an e-mail-heavy, Yale-graduate Boomer-dominated culture, apply.

review_title: A great institution that feels like it's changing for the worse
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Overall, the New School is full of bright, creative, interesting people, and employment here offers some great perqs like tuition waivers, contributions to your pension, four-day summer workweeks, and generous vacation time. However, the spirit of the "old" New School is disappearing in favor of a more corporate approach and I think the institution is a bit adrift.
cons:
Heavily tuition-driven institution with a relatively small endowment means the fiscal strength of the organization fluctuates with enrollment levels. Pay is less than at competing universities, and the near-constant threat of budget cuts and austerity measures mean job security is not a given. 

The opportunities for career advancement vary depending on which division / college you're in, but in general they aren't great. You hit the ceiling pretty fast and raises are not reliably tied to performance reviews, so you may get a 1-2% bump every year or so, or not. 

The New School, a place which used to be full of brilliant people who weren't necessarily career academics, but who had real-world experience and credibility, is changing to a more credential-driven environment making it more like every other institution of higher learning. But given it's shaky finances and lack of a cohesive identity (far more people know of Parsons, a part of the The New School, then know of The New School itself), TNS can't compete with other universities and therefore there is more turnover and employee dissatisfaction.

cons: Serious lack of cohesion amongst different divisions within the university; disconnect between executive management and workers at the general staff level.  Pay is much lower for comparable jobs than at NYU or Columbia; strong/ambitious workers know that and leave for better conditions elsewhere.  VERY hard place to be a new employee, since emphasis is on new hire to "figure it out" for him/herself - hard to get an ID card, hard to get benefits set up correctly, hard to get a working computer or an active email address, etc.  Initiation process for administrative staff is quite different than for faculty, who are valued much more highly.  This is a business, make no mistake, and resources behind the scenes are thin.  Most staff members who stick around are doing it for the benefits, the tuition break for themselves or family members, or because they are long-timers who are comfortable in their jobs.  Many people are both over worked and under paid.

job_title: Entry Level in Charlotte, NC

review_title: Interesting people and nice fringe benefits.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Progressive university setting. Tuition reimbursement a big plus. Colleagues are an interesting and diverse group. Everyone (faculty AND staff) get several weeks off during the winter break around Christmas. Summer Fridays. People generally respectful on the whole - though there are some bad apples. Things are a lot better now that Bob Kerrey is gone (cademics should run universities, not politicians).
cons: Pay is not competitive. Can be a lot of office politics depending on what division/department you're in and who you work for.

job_title: News Anchor in Atlanta, GA
pros: None at all great company
cons: Low pay, schedules could be better

job_title: Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: Decent benefits and great vacation time.  Some great people, but they are slowly moving on to other organizations.  Laid back dress code and atmosphere.
cons:
Working at The New School I learned a little bit, but beyond what I was able to learn from my specific position, The New School was not at all interested in helping with my professional growth.  
Their systems are policies are outdated and there seems to be no desire to update or change anything.
As a policy they do not give merit-based raises.  Meaning that the only way to get a raise is to actually receive a promotion and title change.  So if you work at The New School be prepared to make the same salary for several years. 
There are some good people there but they are few and far between.  
Morale among the employees is very low.

review_title: Lower-level staff are amazing. Upper-leadership in Student Success  enforces white dominant culture.
job_title: Employee in New York, NY
pros: The lower-level staff are amazing activists and agitators. They do all they can to resist policies that are obviously racist, sexist, and detrimental to students success. If it wasn't for my colleagues in arms, I would have left a long time ago.  I don't have faith in Student Success upper-leadership, but the lower-level staff are worth the experience. You will learn so much from these folks.
cons:
No transparency from upper-level leadership
Grossly underpaid compared to others in the same position at comparable schools. We received raises because of NY law, not because the school thought we were underpaid. 
HR is slow to act on credible, consistent, and multiple complaints about the same issues. Sexual assault being one of them.

job_title: Lab Aide in New York, NY
pros: Good pay for little work. Lots of downtime. Unlimited sick days.
cons: The New School review - the school forgets itself as part of an educational institution and attempts to set itself in a fashion that's too administrative; yes, one can be too administrative. There's a level of understanding already ingrained into the system where we, as lab aids, don't have to follow these arbitrary jurisdictions. Like, for example, the establishment has developed an unnecessary grading system. Its a waste of time. I also developed an issue with calling people users. Its a safety net to not offend but it doesn't its on a level that's disrespectful, to me. I'd prefer "student" or person. Gentleman. Lady. Etc.

review_title: You have to accept it for what it is
job_title: Executive Secretary in New York, NY
pros:
Parsons's atmosphere is charged with creativity. You'll soak it up just being there. Design is important in all facets of life and so learning some principles could be useful to one's career. Think about how everything from your car to your shoes to your cereal is designed. There are many classes to take for free. Stimulating people to meet and work with are another plus. 

Health benefits are very generous. Time off accumulates quickly (a norm in higher education).

These are good jobs for people who need flexibility and solid benefits.
cons:
The pay is limited and the same goes for opportunities to really move up the career ladder. Non-for-profits will give you as much responsibility as you are willing to bear - just don't ask for more money. 

Also, if you are a member of the admin union, you'll find that it is a little difficult to move into a non-union position. (The non-union positions are higher up.) It serves as an added barrier.

review_title: I loved teaching at The New School, unfortunately hated their HR.
job_title: Part-Time Faculty in New York, NY
pros: It's a lovely space to explore a different approach to teaching, have more freedom and a welcoming environment for new and radical ideas.
cons: Their HR rules are borderline discriminative, I was denied teaching again due to VISA constraints. They don't hire people under the O1 visa and don't give any explanations as to why. This was explained to me a week before teaching, even though they knew for over a month what VISA I had. No one really explained what happened, they just decided to withdraw the position even though I had a syllabus prepared as well as an income expectation and offer letter. The treatment was awful by the people who manage HR.

review_title: You Must Go Through Hell to Reach Paradise
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Individual managers and co workers can be great. 
Certain departments are dynamic.
A great place to earn a title quickly.
cons:
The overall organization is very one sided.
Blond hair, blue eyed women tend t o be promoted the most.
Everyone is out for themselves, like monkeys climbing out of a barrel. 
You'll earn that title but you'll be paid the same. Raises come every 5 years. 
Managers pick and choose who to celebrate and promote. Simply doing well in your job is not enough to be appreciated. 
They always hire from the outside first. 
Experiences are so relative, it really depends on what department you're in and who your bosses are.  There is no consistent standards for treatment.

review_title: Too much bad attitude not enough gratitude !! Do not work there unless you like verbal abuse by management
job_title: Events in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and holidays off
cons: Bad managers and bad HR. The New School event managers, event directors and event planners need to work on their anger and treatment of all staff. Need to improve pre production of all events. Staff members leave or quit due to a verbal ****storm that they are subjected too every week. Event directors do not know how to use some of the latest and simple programs needed for the jobs to be done.

review_title: Slave Wages and Lots of Politics
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: People can leave at 5pm without feeling guilty because the pay is so lousy. If you are lazy and make your co-workers do your work for you so you can hang out of Facebook instead, you'll fit right in.
cons: The pay is horrible and the health insurance is awful. Raises are virtually non-existent and only for those who do the least work but the most sucking up to managers. if you do get one, it is totally canceled out by annual increases in the amount of out of pocket health care costs you have to pay.

review_title: New School’s full-time faculty unfair treatment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Its Location: New York City
cons: With the exception of New School for Social Research, full-time faculty of all other divisions, (Parsons, Lang, Performing Arts and Schools of Public Engagement) get very little respect from upper administration. Unlike Part-Time Faculty which rights are protected by their union; Full-time faculty is at the mercy of the higher administration. Thick politics, incredible opacity and devious manipulation lead with an iron fist by the President, Provost and Deans offices turn promotion and salary raise process into a sad jock. Although there are many committees, work forces, Faculty Senate and other assigned offices, they exist manly to serve the President’s and Provost’s mission which is incompatible with a democratic / fair process.

review_title: The good, the bad, and the m'eh.
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Plenty of space and time to develop your practice and work the system to your benefit. Lot's of smart, active, and savvy students. REALLY broad spectrum of unique domain programs - Parsons the largest of the group so Design is a big part of the discussion.
cons: Remarkably siloed, slow to change, and suffering through a never-ending identity crisis create a challenging environment for personal growth within the community. It's a large institution with a relatively large number of slow moving, tenured legacy faculty, and a very large Unionized Part-time Faculty. This creates a ton of problems for change and, in an era when the headwinds for the business of academia are rising, this is not a position of strength.

job_title: Graduate Student Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Since I do work in an academic while I am pursuing a graduate degree, luckily my boss is flexible with my schedule and understands that my coursework comes first. Though this is a student employment opportunity, I take my job seriously and I care about who I am communicating and working with, everyday.
cons: From my standpoint, I have no complaints, but I do wish other student employees can be paid as much as I do. I was once in their shoes not too long ago, so I know how hard it can b, especially for graduate students.

review_title: Inventive, creative, and passionate people working for leadership who are petty, misguided and bureaucratic
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The university has a great mission and vision. If you are inclined toward the creative and the progressive, this is the place for you.
cons:
Sometimes, small minds prevail.The new top-heavy, closed circle of leaders, don't always understand the idea of 'shared governance' at a university. They worry more about rules than about letting the brilliance shine.
Also - more emphasis is needed on fundraising.

job_title: Senior Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits (health, dental, vision, retirement and vacation time)
cons:
The New School, while progressive in theory and its outward PR, has shifted towards a corporatized style of management where employees are overworked, under-appreciated, and fearful due to increasing job insecurity. We've watched so many great colleagues (staff AND faculty) disappear, with no transparency, and an expectation that no inquiries into these staff eliminations be made. Those work responsibilities are then piled onto the already overworked remaining staff- without promotion or pay (which is modest and insulting to begin with compared to other institutions). Full-time faculty are also being told their positions are no longer "institutionally needed" and their positions are being eliminated on a large scale. 
The culture of fear and insecurity permeates the environment on all levels.

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Good location with a few attractive buildings, but too bad they spend more money on architecture and signage than they do supporting research.
cons: Poor compensation; extremely low level of workplace engagement; part-time faculty and lower-level staff are treated like second-class citizens; full-time faculty are forced to perpetuate this treatment (e.g., by ensuring part-time faculty don't have opportunities to move into more permanent jobs).

review_title: Excellent institution with room for improvement.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: World class design college in the heart of New York City. Alongside it's excellent reputation for fashion design, it has excellent programs across the board in design from communication design to interior design. Excellent faculty.
cons: Room for improvement with internal communication. Salaries and budgets not inline with other academic institutions. The school would greatly benefit from a central staff lounge, where ideas and better communication would thrive beyond elevator conversations.

review_title: Student Worker at the New School office
job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours, supervisors are really understanding your school workload. Very easy office tasks, even though it is diverse, but easy to learn. Able to learn about far more areas and department of the school rather than the only one we attend.
cons: Other then sometimes there are down time and have nothing to do, or still need to juggle with the job when semester gets crazy, there really isn't any down side.  The only real thing might be difficulty to arrange for internship with the commitment to this job and class schedule at the same time, since it will definitely to be in day time hours.

review_title: My experience working at the New School was fitting for a college student.
job_title: Campus Safety Officer in New York, NY
pros:
Wonderful employers and head supervisors.
Flexible scheduling 
Plenty of post options
Tons of overtime
Great benefits and ties to the school
Days go by quick on busy posts
Good pay
Great union benefits
cons:
No advancement opportunities 
Some posts can be extremely  busy at times yet little to no backup is provided upon request.
Student body actively partake attempting to make work dificult for security on some posts.
Handful of extremely complacent co workers result in others picking up their slack

job_title: Student Assistant II in New York, NY
pros:
Some great people. Friends that I'll talk to for probably the rest of my life
Flexible hours
Very chill duties for student workers
Pretty good wage for a part-time
The School stands for great values
cons:
Disorganized operations
Not sure if administrators follow school values 
As a student worker, I was treated well, but I saw great employees overworked and undercompensated. I've seen people let go without good reason, only driving the institution further into the ground. Only the highest administrators have room for significant raises and promotions, while the rest of the staff seem to be struggling to make enough. The environment seems to be increasingly unhealthy.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Adjuncts earn job security and medical benefits after several semesters. The pay is generous compared to other adjunct professorships I have had. Great freedom is given in the classroom - particularly in comparing projects with equivalent sections of the same course - as long as superior results are achieved.
cons: You get plugged into teaching slots that are very hard to change. This is understandable in a city school that relies of adjuncts more than average. But it is frustrating to not have much leeway in scheduling.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Amazing, progressive and creative student population, great colleagues, some departments have a great work culture and great work/life balance, some have opportunities for advancement, resource-rich, great location, reasonable work hours, good benefits- especially free classes, health insurance and vacation.
cons: Highest level admin is making what was once a very unique university more and more corporate, to the detriment of the university's mission. Low salaries and negligible raises, some departments have a toxic culture and poor work/life balance (as noted, others are excellent and supportive), everyone talks a great talk of being progressive, but many policies and protocol are lacking.  Faculty and staff have brought solutions to senior level admin who do not prioritize addressing this.

review_title: Fantastic university doing interesting work though strained due to national higher education system
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Interesting work, research and art happening all the time
- Great health, sick-day, retirement and vacation packages
- Free tuition for full-time staff
- Location
cons:
- Work-life balance is often askew
- Glaring departmental funding differences = seeing some employees with the best, state of the art equipment (computers, printers, offices, etc.) and others using very outdated technology
- Staff are not given university privileges, for instance we cannot check-out books or media equipment like faculty and students
- We are losing our right to rollover vacation days from year to year. It seems this is an effort to align with a "corporate model", however staff do not enjoy "corporate perks", like bonuses or company phones...things like vacation rollover are our perks!

review_title: horrible corporate attitude, Doesn't care about its professors,quality falling fast.
job_title: Pt Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: The students tend to be good.New Building looks promising even if it looks like a big coffin.Near subways.Beautiful art gallery even if it has horribly boring shows.
cons: Lowered  the credits to graduate yet increased the tuition, so cut 100's of professors hours in half. Part time union members were screwed by both sides in new negotiation where salaries  were cut in half with no explanation. At Parsons ,because of seniority ,classes are now being taught by anyone who wants them even if they have no experience in field. The kids are getting less education and paying more. They do not honor hard work and great professors. They are changing the curriculum from a great design school to a hold hands group sing along. Too bad ,the days of Parsons being a great design school are over. :(

job_title: LSO in New York, NY
pros:
- Good benefits. 403b contributions (very generous), health insurance and transit
- Reasonable work hours, most people do not work beyond 9-5.
- Friendly co-workers
cons:
- Low pay
- Management is generally inept. They either do not know what's going on under them and rely on "spies" to get people to snitch on team members or they micromanage while being incompetent.
- Good managers don't last
- Raises are non-existent
- No upward mobility

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Engaging and challenging work, you learn a lot in the process about the field you teach in. Nice faculty lounge spaces in the new building, convenient facilities overall. Great educational environment.
cons: Not compensated for preparation time, which is a majority of the time spent working on each class. Tech systems for grading and communicating with students still rough to use.

review_title: New School University: College of Performing Arts
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Amazing managerial staff works very hard for the students and teachers experience to be the greatest possible environment in which to work!
cons:
Needs an endowment to expand resources for the betterment of the school. Maximum teaching hours 9 for part-time.
No room to grow into a fulltime position as the school utilizes the many available musicians in NYC in the ever growing part time faculty.

review_title: Though with an Identity Crisis, New School's a Great Place to Work
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Their openness to new ideas: a caring and supportive Human Resources: the current president I think a genuine and truly down-to-earth person (a MUCH better improvement over Bob Kerrey): the people there are generally liberal and student-centered-there's a comraderie: in general great people to work with: the students are great.  I've had many a great conversation with students: there's less a gap between the full-time workers there and those studying and teaching there, since a lot of the full-time workers are or have been studying there as well.
cons: It's not the "major" university it wants to be, so a bit of an identity crisis: policy is constantly shifting and being tinkered with: doesn't pay as highly as other universities: with constant shifting, job security is not as good as it could be: budget is tight, so salaries are often frozen w/ no annual percentage increase.  This has happened over half the years I've worked there.

review_title: Great benefits, flexible, but the bureaucracy is frustrating
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Room for growth, good benefits, liberal ideologies,  interesting people who mostly care about the students, comparably high pay
cons: Can be difficult to make real positive changes, technologically outdated, hard to get noticed

job_title: Security Guard in New York, NY
pros: medical  and dental benefit is great.  Free tuition is you do not mind attending a not accredited institution
cons: SOME OF THE SECURITY GUARDS ARE SHADY.  A lot of perverted guards.  Some sexually harassing the teenage college students.  The managers are aware of the unprofessional security guards but they ignored the issues. There is lot of backstabbing.  Guards are cheap always trying to get stuff out of the student cafeteria.  Civilian stuff in the cafeteria have criminal background.  Some creepy workers.

job_title: Lab Aide in New York, NY
pros:
Flexible schedule for students. 
I liked my coworkers.
For the most part the workers are treated well and respectfully.
This is customer service position, but there isn't a "the customer is always right" mentality. While we were expected to be polite at all times, we were encouraged to be firm with rude customers.
cons:
Management and administration is disorganized at times
Low pay compared to similar jobs at other schools and other student jobs at The New School.
No room for growth

review_title: An awesome place to teach, innovate and be inspired by students
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: The New School is one of the most progressive places to teach. I teach exactly the way I want to, without having to follow rigid rules and guidelines. It's the perfect atmosphere for launching innovative learning experiences. The students have been great - very engaged. As part-time faculty, it's also one of the few universities that offers health and dental insurance for regular part-time professors.
cons: No cons at all. I've been teaching here for 7 years now and plan on being a "lifer"

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities for students to work during the school year on campus. Many of the teachers and students who work at the school are very passionate about what they do and it gives people a strong incentive to work harder.
cons: Very compartmentalized in both work and academia despite being advertised as a cross disciplinary school. While many of the students and teachers have similar issues, especially relating to social justice, they rarely collaborate effectively. There are many attempts and as both an employee and a student you are encouraged too, but they are limited in scope by funding and oversight.

job_title: Resident Advisor in New York, NY
pros:
The relationships you build with the people in Supervisor and Student worker Level. 
The relationships you build with students and the programs they get to put on can be really fun and the opportunity to create a real impact in a students life is the most rewarding part of the department.
Recommend only because of the housing perk and residential impact.
cons: Seems as though management does not like to hear about student worker feedback on their management skills. There is a lot of "because we said so" decisions while there is also very little options for them to flexibly voice their opinions on changes due to them making meetings when most students have class and cannot participate. There have been many times where being a student and focusing on their education has come second or third to being an RA and many times where they have been told their feelings or thoughts are not of concern only that of the residents they look after while HR says that any work related issues cannot be handled by them as they are contracted as student workers and not full-time employees which then puts them in a position where they are forced to endure a difficult work situation.

job_title: Graphic Designer in New York, NY
pros: They are a very design studio centered office, who care about design vs. just getting the work done. You get to work alongside a talented bunch of designers.
cons: There is a good chunk of employees that have an advertising agency background and it's a bit frustrating how they change the vibes of the studio because that's not what its focus is.

job_title: Senior Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Management and supervisors are very flexible when it comes to PT scheduling (assuming you're a FT graduate student)

Very relaxed, positive, and progressive environment where being unique is the norm.
cons:
Student assistant positions are under paid considering you're in New York City.

Some PT clerical positions are unionized, which nets you a smaller paycheck at  the end of the week.

job_title: Part-Time Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Students are mostly open-minded and enjoy being challenged. They are a pleasure to teach.
cons: The administration is terrible:  despite being supposedly "progressive," they are covertly racist and sexist, preferring to offer the most opportunities to (white) men.  I know of at least several instances where less qualified men were promoted over women.

review_title: Good working environment, but very corporate
job_title: Academic Advisor in New York, NY
pros: They treat employees with respect and care about work environment. I get along with all employees and am treated fairly.
cons: Environment has become more and more corporate and we are becoming less as educators and more like customer service reps. This job could be handled by almost anyone who has skills to be organized, where as it used to be more a field for people who understood higher-ed and the field they advised.

job_title: Tech in New York, NY
pros:
progressive institute, interesting, good benefits, job security etc 
tuition waivers, interesting architecture and design, it was overall ok but eh
cons: low pay, bad management, from the top to the bottom lack of responsibility and accountability, very low pay, very very low pay and yet everything was expensive

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: New School is for individuals who want to create their education. For those who work there, it is about facilitating educational growth, and life transformation. Undergraduate degrees are available without cost, and Graduate degrees are comped, but you pay the taxes on the tuition - still cheaper than a full grad degree.
cons: Bureaucratic processes can be exhausting. Still working out issues with administration and leadership, but it is on the mend.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Liberal, open, supportive. Staff are very passionate about their work and teams work together to solve problems. People are clearly their top priority and while there is some bureaucracy it is better than most institutions I have worked in. Creativity abounds as directors support their staff. Very social justice minded and eco friendly.  Everyone always asks" how can this help students?" and are focused on student success.
cons: The university is so big that it is hard to know everyone! Some departments are understaffed.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Learn to use Word, Excel, Publisher, and copier machine. Very rewarding job, I learned to change a copy machine turner, send faxes and scans. I learned to be more engaging and social with people and met some interesting characters.
cons: It is a federal work study job so the payroll is fixed to federal work study aide.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
- Decent work environment...
- Very good facilities
- Pretty good coworkers
- Pay rate is good
- Stable depending on position
- Lots of social events/mixers for workers
cons:
- Lack of empathy from higher-ups
- Very seldom advancement opportunities
- Totally archaic payroll system
- President forced to resign due to controversies and pressure.
- Some departments are grossly underfunded. Seemingly constant budget issues

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Working as a grad student means that you're well connected with the university community. The pay isn't bad either. All in all, there are pros and cons. Everyone needs to work in NY.
cons: Working while in graduate school means that you won't have as much time to work on your course work as, say, a student who's not working.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: A lot of free time to apply for other jobs? Recognizable name in the NYC area.
cons: Low salary; limited opportunities for growth; negative and immature work environment

review_title: Could be a great place to work
job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Folks are friendly, great location.  Lots of opportunity to take courses.
cons:
The school saves money by not enrolling new employees in their health care plan right away.  Depending on when you are hired, you will wait a month before your benefits kick in.  

If you take a class, which you can after your probation period (3 months) you are not allow to transfer credits.

job_title: Web Producer in New York, NY
pros:
Great Vacation Time
Summer Fridays
Can leave at 5pm without feeling guilty
Work is relatively easy, leaving time for learning other things
cons:
Poor Management
Horrible Office Culture. 
Lots of managers lead with fear rather than cooperative minded approach
No room for growth
Bureaucratic

review_title: The New School was a very exciting environment!
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The New School for Social Research is a cutting edge university doing incredible research at the forefront of many fields. It was a great work environment, the faculty and staff are very committed to what they do, and pleasant to be around and work with.
cons: The university itself has a lot of funding issues, and needs to reevaluate salaries and budgets. Graduate students in the Social Research division definitely need more teaching opportunities!

job_title: Marketing in New York, NY
pros: The leadership are committed to being proactive in upgrading to current business practices without losing the academic vision of the schools.
cons: Part faculty distrust; part lack of transparency adds to a dysfunctional atmosphere that impedes middle management and hurts progress to move the schools forward in a very competitive market

review_title: Tishman Environment and Design Center Research Atmosphere
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: TEDC is plugged into some of the leading causes and advances regarding environmental sustainability in the fields of waste, environmental justice, and city-level resiliency and adaptation policies.
cons: The center is going through some growing pains so employees are often asked to do work outside of their designated roles. The longer I was there the less engage I felt because my direct supervisors never bothered to check in with me.

job_title: Peer Career Ambassador in New York, NY
pros: The team I worked with at career services was extremely passionate about helping the students find their relative jobs and internships; I really admired their commitment to the work. Very organized, easy to get your bearings just starting.
cons: Not much to say. I would say the department itself wasn't always allocated the amount of time and attention it could have been from the university. Many students didn't know about the asset of the Career Service branch.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The New School is a place with great colleagues and excellent benefits. Summer Fridays off, 22 days vacation, etc. Reasonable hours (generally 9 - 5) and a flexible culture. People are supportive, smart. Great place for quirky, diverse personalities and those interested in the arts.
cons: Tuition driven institution in a changing higher education environment. Old systems and processes often make it difficult to get things accomplished. Budget is strained.

review_title: Do Not Accept A Position Here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
It depends. If you're a white female, low-mid thirties, have little to now experience and not the required education, then you'll have plenty of pros. These pros include career advancement (including unmerited, and on-the-spot promotions), higher salaries, being able to actively bully and discriminate against anyone, and of course coming in late every day, taking an extended lunch, then leaving early.

For everyone else, there is unlimited sick time which you can use to find another job.
cons: Not being a white female in your low-mid thirties.
